conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze forces on block A in both scenarios, calculate normal and friction forces using angles and masses.
Figure A: Block A on inclined plane at 37°. Figure B: Block A with cylinder B on inclined plane at 30°.
In Figure A, block A is at rest, net force is zero. Gravity resolved into parallel (Mg sin 37°) and perpendicular (Mg cos 37°) components.
Parallel component (Mg sin 37°) balanced by frictional force (f) acting up the slope.
Perpendicular component (Mg cos 37°) balanced by normal force (N) from inclined plane on block A.
In Figure B, cylinder B placed between block A and inclined plane. Mass of cylinder is m, mass of block A is M = 4m.
Normal force (N) on block A is weight of block A minus weight of cylinder B: N = Mg cos 30° - mg.
Frictional force (f) is component of weight of block A parallel to inclined plane: f = Mg sin 30°.
Since cylinder is smooth, frictional force between block A and inclined plane is same as in Figure A.
Equating frictional forces from both scenarios: Mg sin 30° = Mg sin 37° - (Mg cos 30° - mg).
Substitute values: sin 37° = 0.6, cos 30° = 0.8, solve for frictional force, find f = Mg sin 30°.
Given M = 4m, frictional force is f = 4mg.
